transcript.title: Water Management Crucial for Australia
transcript.content:
September 13, 1996

WATER MANAGEMENT CRUCIAL FOR AUSTRALIA

The crucial need for improved research and management of Australia's most valuableÂ inland water resources, the Murray-Darling and Great Artesian Basins, has beenÂ underscored by today's meeting of the Prime Minister's Science and EngineeringÂ Council ( PMSEC).

I was pleased to receive a direct briefing from leaders of the science community andÂ representatives of the major science users on this and other important issues andÂ priorities.

The briefing stressed the importance to Australian agriculture and to the conservationÂ of our fragile environment of informed management of these Basins, using the bestÂ available scientific knowledge.

The issue of managing our inland waters is vital for the future of agriculture, theÂ environment and human health. The Government's National Heritage Trust will play aÂ central role in providing that proper management, and the $ 1 billion to be provided toÂ that Trust from the partial sale of Telstra demonstrates the commitment of theÂ Government to well-informed management and sustainability.

Some concerns raised today included the need to conserve water in the Great ArtesianÂ Basin, water quality, including problems caused by salinity and agricultural chemicals,Â and the crucial role of allocating water in the Basins to ensure economically andÂ environmentally sustainable use.

Improving our environment has always been a key issue in the bush and today'sÂ discussion and future work demonstrate the Coalition Government's strongÂ commnitment to regional Australia.

The forum further demonstrates the Government's practical green agenda.

I have asked the Ministers for the Environment and Primary Industries and Energy toÂ report on how Australia can best apply the information that was presented at theÂ meeting to practical outcomes.

I have also asked the Ministers for Industry, Science and Tourism and Science andÂ Technology to examine other issues raised. These include the commercialÂ opportunities offered by genetic modification of cut flowers; control of rabbits throughÂ mortality and fertility control; and the awareness and understanding of science atÂ primary school level.

of research, science education and national scientific facilities.
